Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mobilizing human rights frames

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project attempts to situate the ways in which legal mobilization and social movement activism are shaped by social and political contexts, especially in regimes where the political space is constrained. It specifically examines the impact on perceived political acceptance in illiberal regimes, which have a noted hostility to human rights frames, of adopting a human rights frame as a substitute when approaching identity issues.

The research plan involves participant observation over 12 months with 3 social movement organizations and approximately 50 semi-structured interviews. The project offers the potential for increasing understanding of the ability of social movements to shift frames in ways that enhance their social desirability, in both liberal and illiberal societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research answers two primary questions: how do Hong Kong LGBT activists become categorized as either “local” or “expat” and how do these categories shape the strategies and tactics they use. The terms “local” and “expat” are not well-defined, and yet activists are often claiming certain types of people are locals and others are expats. Those in the middle—Western-born and -raised people whose parents emigrated from Hong Kong, or Hong Kong-born people who were educated abroad—frequently move and communicate between the two groups of people. Locals and these people in the middle are also more adept than expats at translating human rights concepts and aspects of the global LGBT movement both into the local language (Cantonese) and into locally recognized and acceptable ideas. Closeness to the target population matters in this translation work. The closeness that locals and people in the middle rely upon is a combination of shared language, the target’s assumption that they share the same Hong Kong identity, and a deep understanding of acceptable norms and behaviors. When expats (Westerners living and working in Hong Kong, as well as local elites) try to translate, they are generally perceived as “foreign” or “importing” concepts from the West. Through activists’ work on trying to pass laws protecting against sexual orientation and gender identity discrimination, allowing transgender people to legally change their gender, and recognizing same-sex relationships, I have found that translating legal and human rights concepts is an important tactic in activists’ toolboxes.
